data.title: DEATH OF NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN

data.text:
It is one of the ironies of history that

men we often remembered for their

spectacular failures rather than for many

wise, inconspicuous services they may

render to mankind. This is unjust, but

human and inevitable. So Neville Cham-

berlain will be remembered for Munich,

which in retrospective judgment has had

to be written down as a failure, but which

at the time was rightly acclaimed as a

splendid piece of statesmanship.

The Munich agreement was signed on

September 30, 1938. Within 12 months

Britain was at war with Germany.

Within 20 months Poland, Denmark, Nor-

way, Holland, Belgium, Luxemburg, and

France were prostrate under the heel of

Germany, and Britain and her Empire

faced the enemy alone.

Men will not forget Mr. Chamberlain's

"peace for our time," but doubtless some

few of them will also remember the

tragedy of his speech in the Commons

when war became inevitable . . . "all

that I have worked for, all that I had

hoped for, has fallen in fragments about

me." . . .

So spectacular were the closing months

of Neville Chamberlain's life that the

fact that his entire political career was

spectacular is prone to be overlooked.

Five years after he first entered the

House of Commons he was Chancellor

of the Exchequer—an almost unparalleled

advance.

A second son of the famous Joseph

Chamberlain, and half-brother of the

picturesque Sir Austen, Neville Chamber-

lain — or Arthur Neville Chamberlain, to

give him his full name — apparently

began adult life without a thought of

the political career which most of the

male members of his family regarded as

the only possible career. Born at Birm-

ingham on March 18, 1869, he was edu-

cated at Rugby and Mason College,

Birmingham, and when his education

was complete went into business. For

many years he lived in the Bahamas, but

returned to England some time before

the last war.

His first step into public life was as a

humble Birmingham councillor. Pres-

ently, however, he was an alderman, to

become, in 1915, Lord Mayor. His work

In this position brought him to the notice

of the Government, and in the following

year he was made Director-General of

National Service, a post which he held

until 1917.

In 1918 the way was smoothed for him

to enter the Commons as a Conservative,

in the family tradition. Once in, how-

ever, his hitherto rapid advancement

seemed to receive a check. He remained

an inconspicuous member of the back

benches for four years. People referred

to him as "the other Chamberlain," and

looked on him as "just a super town

clerk." He was a disappointment as a

Chamberlain. He lacked the grace, the

charm, the grandeur of style, the orchid,

and monocle of his father, Joseph

—dead before he entered the House—

qualities bequeathed in toto to his half-

brother, Austen. Nor had he the "com-

mon touch" which so often makes a suc-

cessful politician.

He became slowly known, however, as

a financial authority, and with the break-

up of the Lloyd George Coalition Go-

vernment, he became Postmaster-

General, and, a year later, Paymaster-

General. Here his financial knowledge

was again noticed, and in 1923 he was

made Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Before he was able to introduce a

Budget the Conservative Government fell.

The Labour Government which succeeded

it was defeated towards the end of 1924,

and Chamberlain was expected to resume

the Chancellorship, but instead he be-

came Minister for Health, a post which

he held until 1929, when the Baldwin

Government went down to defeat, and

Labour again took the reins.

In the ensuing years Neville Chamber-

lain was noticed mainly because of his

bitter clashes with Philip Snowden,

Labour Chancellor of the Exchequer.

When the first National Government was

formed Chamberlain held his old post as

Minister for Health until the Govern-

ment was confirmed in office by the

general election of 1931, when he re-

placed Snowden, under whose Budget a

section of Britain was literally groaning.

The gold standard had been left behind,

and the country's finances needed careful

handling. From Chamberlain they got

it. The most orthodox of orthodox finan-

ciers, he allayed alarm, and within two

years was able to modify Snowden's

"crisis Budget" and reduce taxation. Yet,

when the rearmament of Britain began

in 1936 he did not hesitate to increase

taxes.

In the following year, when Lord Bald-

win (then Mr.) decided to retire, Neville

Chamberlain was the obvious choice as

his successor. He stepped down from

the Prime Minlstership to make way for

Mr. Winston Churchill and a National

Government when news reached Britain

of Hitler's invasion of the Lowlands.

Shortly afterward he underwent a sur-

gical operation. On leaving hospital he

went to the country, and at first his health

seemed to improve, but later his condition

became weaker and caused his family and

friends grave anxiety. He did not appear

again in the House of Commons.
